[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Code injection] Can an attacker specify a malicious git_hash pointing to a compromised repository revision containing backdoored framework code, allowing them to inject malicious bytecode into framework upgrade proposals that would be deployed network-wide? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Repository substitution] Can an attacker perform a man-in-the-middle attack during Repository::clone() by redirecting APTOS_GIT_PATH to a malicious repository containing modified framework packages that steal funds or break consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Git reference manipulation] Can an attacker exploit repository.revparse_ext() by providing specially crafted revision strings (e.g., '../../malicious', '../../../../../etc/passwd') to access unauthorized files or execute arbitrary code? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Checkout race condition] Is there a TOCTOU vulnerability between Repository::clone() and repository.checkout_tree() where an attacker could swap repository contents to inject malicious code before checkout completes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Commit verification bypass] Does the code verify git commit signatures or validate the integrity of cloned repositories, or can an attacker push unsigned/malicious commits to compromise framework upgrades? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [DNS poisoning] Can an attacker poison DNS records for 'github.com' to redirect Repository::clone() to a malicious server hosting backdoored framework code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Repository URL injection] Is APTOS_GIT_PATH hardcoded securely, or can configuration changes inject a malicious URL that downloads compromised framework packages during proposal generation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Path traversal] Can an attacker manipulate relative_package_path values in package_path_list to escape the intended directory structure using sequences like '../../../' to access sensitive system files? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Directory confusion] Can an attacker exploit the logic that chooses between temp_root_path and aptos_core_path() to compile malicious packages from unexpected locations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Symlink attack] Can an attacker create symbolic links in temp_root_path that redirect package compilation to malicious directories containing backdoored Move code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Temp path prediction] Is TempPath::new() generating predictable temporary directory names that an attacker could pre-populate with malicious framework packages? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [File name injection] Can package_path.file_name().unwrap() be exploited with crafted file names containing special characters (e.g., '../malicious.move', 'null\\x00.move') to bypass validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Path normalization bypass] Are package paths properly normalized before use, or can attackers use Windows/Unix path separator confusion ('\\' vs '/') to access unauthorized files? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Address injection] Can an attacker inject malicious account addresses by manipulating publish_addr values in package_path_list (e.g., '0xMALICIOUS', '0x0', '0xFFFFFFFF') to deploy framework code under unauthorized accounts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Address parsing bypass] Can AccountAddress::from_hex_literal() be exploited with malformed addresses (e.g., negative values, overflows, special characters) to cause crashes or undefined behavior? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Package address mismatch] Is there validation that the publish_addr in package_path_list matches the actual deployment address in the compiled package, preventing address confusion attacks? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [System address privilege escalation] Can an attacker specify system addresses like '0x1', '0x3', '0x4' to generate proposals that deploy malicious code with privileged framework-level permissions? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Version downgrade attack] Can an attacker set bytecode_version to an old, vulnerable version with known security bugs to create exploitable framework upgrades? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Version overflow] Can bytecode_version (u32) be set to MAX_VALUE or other extreme values causing integer overflows in downstream bytecode processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Incompatible bytecode] Can mismatched bytecode versions between different packages in package_path_list cause runtime failures, consensus divergence, or VM crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Future version exploitation] Can an attacker specify a future bytecode_version that hasn't been tested/audited to exploit unknown vulnerabilities in unreleased VM features? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Version zero bypass] Does bytecode_version = 0 bypass certain security checks or enable deprecated dangerous features that could compromise framework security? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Optimization bypass] Can an attacker modify BuildOptions to disable 'extended-framework-optimizations' causing generated bytecode to be gas-inefficient or contain security vulnerabilities? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Source map injection] Can with_srcs: true be exploited to inject malicious source code comments or metadata that could confuse auditors or hide backdoors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-release-builder/src/components/framework.rs] [Function: generate_upgrade_proposals()] [Error map manipulation] Can with_error_map: true be used to inject misleading error messages that hide attack vectors or cause incorrect error handling? (Low)
